byline.contributor: Mark Mazzetti and John Ismay contributed reporting.
byline.original: By C. J. CHIVERS and ERIC SCHMITT

abstract: Central Intelligence Agency purchased and destroyed at least 400 nerve-agent rockets made by Saddam Hussein's government in 1980s from single Iraqi source between 2005 and 2006, ensuring weapons did not fall into hands of terrorists; revelation of formerly secret operation raises concerns about military's failure to warn troops of dangers or provide proper medical care for those exposed to chemicals.
lead_paragraph: The purchase plan, which began in 2005 and involved a secretive seller, yielded at least 400 warheads, some containing the nerve agent sarin, officials said.

headline.main: C.I.A. Is Said to Have Bought and Destroyed Iraqi Chemical Weapons
headline.print_headline: C.I.A. Is Said to Have Bought and Destroyed Iraqi Chemical Weapons

snippet: The purchase plan, which began in 2005 and involved a secretive seller, yielded at least 400 warheads, some containing the nerve agent sarin, officials said.
